caption: I had to come to see that it was close during summer. When you have a website and you are closing a museum a basic thing to do is to place un BIG and in RED that you are close.
I went on a Tuesday when it was supposed to be open and it was not. Disappointing especially because it is not near any other attraction.

All in French,  of course, but Google translate saved the day.   For someone who's interested in water quality and infrastructure it answered a lot of my questions.   I got lucky and had the exhibition to myself, as I heard a loud school group just exiting.  Check out their website where it shows the water quality and map of where the public drinking fountains are.  Also, it shows the free sparkling water (petillante sp?) Sources are.  Imagine that, free sparkling water to the masses?!  What a city Pairs is!  Also, you can Google maps search for something like: Fontaine Petillante.
The tour is really important. And make us realize should really use as less as possible pollution products, because it is really have bad impact to the environment.
This place is free, fun for kids and adults. This place is about water and sea creatures
Interesting history of water in Paris, all in French, free
very good
Just the temple of water of Paris!!!
Well
üëçüèΩ ‚Ä¶
GOOD
OK
Original
Quite educational. Exhibition on the history of water distribution in Paris + ecological exhibition on the problem of plastics in the oceans...
I have visited this museum 4 times now and I never get tired of it! The permanent exhibition is very interesting and the temporary exhibitions fascinating. For young and old alike and it‚Äôs free!

Yesterday, August 22, relying on information from the internet (opening at 10 a.m.), I wanted to show a foreign friend around the exhibition.  I was outraged to see the sign in front of the entrance ‚Äúclosed on June 27‚Äù without any other indication!!! Needless to say, my disappointment - and my shame - in the face of such negligence and lack of seriousness which puts Paris to shame!!!!!

It's free, hence the 3 stars. It‚Äôs a shame that this industrial building is not better highlighted. Very few explanations regarding water treatment, even films would have been welcome.  Very few objects. The waste exhibition mobilizes a large part (too bad we don't take into account the thousands of tons of masks in petrochemicals...). And where did the Wallace Fountain go? Sold?
Nice building under renovation near the Seine but the black wall in front spoils everything!

A museum which is starting to be one of my favorites in Paris. Of course, it's a little out of the way, but the exhibitions (generally on water, sustainable development, future energies, etc.) are always interesting and well presented... And what's more, it's free!

An interesting discovery, both on the history of water in Paris and for the exhibition part. The current exhibition on street art with water is truly rich in diversity of works. The welcome is sober but warm. The only downside is that there are no outdoor facilities for bicycles! The City of Paris' bicycle policy is still not coherent!
I went there today with my son's class, it's really very interesting, I learned quite a few things and the person who received us was really very welcoming and warm, I really liked this afternoon
Exhibition in September. Highly recommended and free
A very nice exhibition. Looking forward to the next one!
Nice place on the history of Paris water and the old factory. In addition ephemeral exhibition

Water help! We salute the action of the city of Paris in wanting to raise awareness of water issues üåä in Paris. The building is located in a former industrial hall. The public organization "Eau de Paris" offers a permanent exhibition dedicated to the capital's water supply plan, temporary exhibitions, activities for children and thematic meetings. This space allows you to have a good, fun time, especially for the youngest.
Despite the information on the site, the Pavilion is closed this Wednesday at 1 p.m. No info at the door, not even ‚Äúon strike‚Äù perhaps? This is undoubtedly what we call respect for the public.

Interesting. We learn a few things about Paris water. We can still doubt the interest of such a place when we know that it is paid for by the royalties of Parisians... Is there not something better to do with public money?

A well-established exhibition, with explanations accessible to all, that's what attracted me to the Water Pavilion. But I had to hang on and really want to go: the first day, Monday June 3, it was 10:30 a.m., but it was closed... I went back at 5 p.m. after finding on the internet (because this information is not put on the entrance door or on the exhibition poster) that it only opened from 2 to 6 p.m., but no luck: it was already closed at 5 p.m. I had to go back a third time to find it open but the young lady at the entrance, engaged in long telephone conversations, made no gesture towards me, neither to pass by, nor to wait.... She ignored me royally, so after waiting a long time, I ended up entering and visiting the exhibition. Fortunately, it was worth the trip (one, not three...) Hence three stars instead of four or five.
The water pavilion is closed in August 2019 contrary to the times given on the site. I was hoping to see the Wallace Fountains exhibit and found myself in front of a closed door. Damage !
Very beautiful place that I highly recommend if you want to learn more about the waters of Paris. The museum is designed for young and old.
Very large premises but little to see. A static model. Posters to read (no need to travel to read). A very short video. In short, I didn't learn much there.
It was a great, very instructive initiative... Losing momentum. The particularity of the objectives has disappeared in favor of clich√©s about the climate. Too bad ü•¥ ‚Ä¶
Interesting presentation of drinking water circuits in Paris. Less impressive than the Paris sewers but worth a look when passing through the neighborhood.
Interesting place to discover the historical aspect of the non-potable water network of the city of Paris. But it is above all a temporary exhibition space.
Visit the exhibition ‚Äúplasticized oceans and seas. Exhibition on the damage caused by plastic waste on our oceans, seas and rivers A must see for awareness
Interesting exhibition on pollution in our oceans. Small but nice museum.

Place where we learn a lot: the water we consume where does it come from? Who is in charge of it and how? Parisians, it is time to find out...in addition to exhibitions, free entry, this place is open to all.
small exhibitions that talk about water what is really nice to do are the walks in Paris that they organize whose theme is water
